div.p:
I am a boy, I am a girl. My
skin is a shade darker and my
hair a bit thicker than most
students. I play the dating game
differently too, I am a Negro
who has become integrated into
the fabric of the University, and
I stay aloof from all-Negro social
cliques. People who share my
perspective often hold similar,
though not identical points of
view.

“I think white girls are de-
finitelydefinitely more friendly than white
boys,” related a pretty young
freshman. “I feel that white
girls are particularly friendly
with Negro boys. There is such
a limited amount of Negro boys
that this really gets on my
nerves.”

“That’s typical female jeal-
ousyjealousy jeal­-
ousy,” laughed a Negro boy, hear-
inghearing these comments. But the
attractive coed had more to say,
"If it was a fair interchange,
I might not mind,” she said,
“But white boys show little in-
terestinterest in Negro girls, I have
the distinct feeling,” she said,
“that when a white boy sees an
attractive Negro girl, it crosses
his mind that she is Negro and
he then pays no further attention
to her.

“They must have some particu-
larparticular impression that Negro girls
are dirty and ignorant. I’ve
really tried to figure out the
mental processes involved be-
causebecause you can’t tell me that
boys won’t recognize a nice look-
inglooking girl right away.”

On the other side of the dating
game is Dave, also a Negro, He
notes that often white girls exer-
ciseexercise a certain friendliness to-
wardtoward him, but he exercises some
caution in interdating.

“You can ask a girl out right
away--if you like getting shot
down!” he commented, “But most
of the time in your associations
you basically know who would
(go out with you) and who
wouldn’t,” he said. If a Negro
boy and a white girl get to know
each other and build up an ex-
changeexchange “you ask her out then.”

Among the students interview-
edinterviewed, boys have interdated more
frequently than girls. One coed
who has been asked out by white
boys has always “declined. I
might feel a little strange,” she
explained, “but the person I am
with might feel worse.”

"My father just wouldn’t ap-
proveapprove," offered another coed,
“I am not going to say ‘No, I
never will interdate,’ If it comes
along, I might. But, . .I think
the chances are less for me
than for a Negro boy.”

Most of these Negroes have
definite views about the colored
students who sit together in the
Main Dining Hall and in the Stu-
dentStudent Union. “It’s sociological,”
explained one Negro. “These
kids, for the most part, come
from schools where there were
90 per cent Negroes. They have
never been in an integrated en-
vironmentenvironment and therefore remain
together here.”

“They're mostly commuters
(in the Union)," analyzed an-
otheranother. “They just go to the Union
because there is really nothing
else for them to do in between
classes--except to study. You
can’t do that all the time, and
it is nice to relax in the Union,”
"To me, the Student Union

Negro is the Negro that every-
bodyeverybody expects to see,” asserted
a Negro coed with much resent-
mentresentment, “I don’t go to the Union,”
she continued. "I don’t care to
classify myself. I find it posi-
tivelypositively revolting. All my people
are congregated in one section
playing pinochle, laughing and
talking.

"When I sit with the Negroes
in the dining hall," she added,
"they make me feel more like a
Negro than white people do."

A Negro clique, she said, im-
pliesimplies that «the white world has
me down and I have to go hunt
up my people.”

"I picked the University of
Maryland as opposed to Negro
colleges in Baltimore. I still
have to live in a white man’s
world, therefore I have to learn
to live with them. The only way
you can let people know that you
are like them is to associate
with them.”
Negro students who spend their

time in the Union, however, dis-
agreedisagree with these viewpoints,
"These were my friends in high-
schoolhighschool," professed one boy. «I
came to college and stayed with
them. It’s natural to stay with
people you know. Many white
students segregate themselves,
too, and only stay with people
they associated with prior to
college.”

The Negro community on cam-
puscampus is not homogeneous in ideas--
nor can the Negro community
be considered an identifiable sub-­
group, some Negro students
stay segregated. Others inte-
grateintegrate to varying degrees. Like
all individuals, each Negro has
a distinct set of opinions. Even
college holds a different place
in each one’s scheme of values.

"I think college is a place
where you do a lot of learning,"
expressed one Negro,- “All your
life you have been taught this and
that. Now your intellect begins
to take over ...You learn whether
it was all a big hoax,”

In this generation, he reflected,
there are many opportunities for
whites and Negroes to interre-
lateinterrelate, many more opportunities
than "our parents” had. Inter-
racialInterracial contact stimulates thought
and discussion.

"Sooner or later I hope every-
bodyeverybody will be one big happy family
—all mixed up. Things could
really swing,” one Negro sug-
gestedsuggested. “Or, then again, we
could have a recession.”
